Fig. 1 Schematic show the process of synthesis of the Cu/C catalyst during synthesis and heating. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Structural characterization of the Cu-MOF precursors. (a) The XRD patterns of the as prepared Cu-MOF precursor, (b) The Rietveld refinement of the X-ray diffraction pattern for Cu-MOF-DM, (c) FT-IR spectra of the as prepared Cu-MOF precursor, (d) The TG curves of the as prepared Cu-MOF precursor. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Morphology Analysis (SEM) of (a) Cu-MOF-D, (b) Cu-MOF-DM, (b1) Overall structure of Cu-MOF-DM, (c) Cu-MOF-DE, (d) Cu-MOF-DEG, (e) Cu-MOF-DI, (f) Cu-MOF-DO, (g) Cu-MOF-DH. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Structural characterization of the Cu/C Catalysts. (a) The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Cu/C-D; Cu/C-DM; Cu/C-DE; Cu/C-DEG; Cu/C-DI; Cu/C-DO; Cu/C-DH, (b) The XPS survey scan of Cu/C-DM catalysts, (c) C 1 s core-level spectrum of Cu/C-DM, (d) Cu 2p doublet region of Cu/C-DM, (e) Cu LMM Auger transition of Cu/C-DM, (f) O 1 s spectral region of Cu/C-DM. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Comparative analysis of reaction conditions and catalyst performance in Cu/C catalysts (a) Influence of reaction time on LA conversion and GVL yield over Cu/C-DM at 130 °C and 3 MPa H₂, (b) Temperature-dependent catalytic activity profiles over Cu/C-DM for 6 h under 3 MPa H₂, (c) Influence of hydrogen pressure on LA conversion and GVL yield, (d) Comparative evaluation of LA conversion and GVL yields over Cu/C-DM and reference catalysts (Cu/C-D; Cu/C-DE; Cu/C-DEG; Cu/C-DI; Cu/C-DO; Cu/C-DH) under optimized conditions (130 °C, 3 MPa, 6 h). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Graph of β/α value in relation to (a) BET surface area of Cu-MOF precursor, (b) yield of GVL of Cu/C catalyst, symbol shapes denote distinct solvent compositions (see legend). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 AIMD simulation snapshots of (a) The solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DM precursors contains MeOH, DMF, FDCA and Cu²⁺; (b) The solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DH precursors which contain H2O, DMF, FDCA and Cu²⁺; (c) Radial distribution functions of Cu2+-O(MeOH), Cu2+-N(DMF) and Cu2+-O(FDCA) pairs of the solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DM precursors; (d) Radial distribution functions of Cu2+-O(H2O), Cu2+-N(DMF) and Cu2+-O(FDCA) pairs of the solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DH precursors. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Cu LMM Auger spectra of (a) Cu/C-D, (b) Cu/C-DM, (c) Cu/C-DE, (d) Cu/C-DEG, (e) Cu/C-DI, (f) Cu/C-DO, (g) Cu/C-DH, (h) Cu LMM results (surface Cu0, Cu+, Cu2+ and Cu0+ Cu+/Cu2+ ratios) of the sets of Cu/C catalysts. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Geometric structure of Cu species on the Cu/C-DM catalyst (a) TEM images and corresponding EDS mapping (color scheme: C, red；Cu, green; O, purple) of Cu/C-DM catalyst, (b) TEM image with elemental overlay, (c) HRTEM images of the Cu/C-DM catalyst show the formation of Cu/Cu2O heterostructures (color scheme: Cu, blue; Cu2O, orange). No. 37 Chaoqian Road Beijing 102299 PR China The synthesis of value-added chemicals from renewable biomass is becoming increasingly important in the transition to a sustainable and low-carbon energy system. Herein, we demonstrate a solvent-polarity modulation strategy to engineer biomass-derived Cu-MOF using 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) as a renewable ligand, where tailored β/α ratios via Kamlet-Taft parameters balance nucleation-growth kinetics to optimize textural properties. Pyrolyzed Cu-MOF at 500 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere yield the Cu/C catalysts, which were subsequently employed in the selective hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL). Among the various solvents used, the Cu-MOF precursor synthesized in a mixed solvent of methanol and N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) demonstrated the highest catalytic performance, outperforming those synthesized in other solvents. This highlights the significant impact of solvent selection on the structure of Cu-MOF, which in turn affects their hydrogenation activity. Advanced characterization confirming that the uniform Cu dispersion (confirmed by HRTEM mapping) and Cu⁰/Cu⁺ electronic synergy (via Cu Auger analysis) enhanced hydrogenation performance. Additionally, the biomass-derived catalysts exhibited excellent durability. Overall, this research provides a promising approach to develop highly efficient catalysts using renewable ligands and demonstrates the potential of regulating catalyst properties through the strategic selection of solvents, as informed by Kamlet-Taft parameters. Graphical Abstract Utilizing renewable FDCA ligands, solvent polarity engineering (guided by Kamlet-Taft parameters β/α) regulates Cu-MOF assembly, followed by pyrolysis to construct the Cu/C catalysts. Synergistic Cu⁰-Cu⁺ interfaces and well-dispersed Cu species on Cu/C-DM catalysts drive excellent catalytic performance on hydrogenation of Levulinic Acid (LA) to γ-Valerolactone (GVL). Keywords Solvent effect Kamlet-Taft parameters Biomass-derived Cu-MOF Levulinic acid hydrogenation Geometric-electronic synergy Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the face of escalating global energy demands and increasingly severe environmental challenges, the pursuit of sustainable and clean energy solutions has emerged as a common objective for nations worldwide. Biomass is recognized as a significant source of renewable building blocks that can effectively substitute petroleum-derived feedstocks[1–5]. The efficient conversion and utilization of biomass are paramount to establishing a low-carbon ecosystem. LA [6,7], an essential biomass-derived platform compound, can be obtained through the pyrolysis and hydrolysis of lignocellulosic materials via a straightforward and highly productive acid hydrolysis process. A multitude of value-added chemicals can be derived directly from LA, including GVL [8,9], valeric acid, 1,4-pentanediol, et al. Notably, GVL serves as an additive in fuels, solvent, food additive, and plasticizer. To date, various catalysts have been developed and engineered to facilitate the efficient conversion of LA to GVL[10–12]. Precious metal catalysts (e.g. palladium[13], platinum[14], rhodium[15], ruthenium[16]) typically exhibit higher activity and selectivity, rendering them effective for specific hydrogenation reactions. For example, Anqi Wang, et al. developed an efficient palladium nanoparticle catalyst for the selective synthesis of GVL and valeric acid (VA) from biomass-derived LA, with GVL selectivity (88.5 %) and VA yield of 45.1 %[13]. Cao, et al. reported a novel 0.85 wt% Ru/ZrO2@C material, this catalyst demonstrated efficient conversion of LA to GVL in a highly acidic aqueous solution (pH=1)[17]. However, the high cost and limited resources of precious metal catalysts presents a significant barrier to their large-scale industrial application. In contrast, non-precious metal catalysts offer a more economical alternative. Wang, et al. reported the preparation of Co@NC samples, which exhibited 100 % conversion of LA and a 100 % yield of GVL when reacted at 190 °C and 1.9 MPa H2 for two hours [18]. Additionally, supported bimetallic catalysts have shown remarkable catalytic properties, for instance, Popova et al. synthesized a bimetallic (Cu-Ni) catalyst based on a KIT-6 mesoporous silica/zeolite composite carrier, achieving 100 % conversion of LA at 250 °C and atmospheric pressure [19]. Nonetheless, supported catalysts are prone to decreased catalytic activity due to the sintering of metal nanoparticles[20] and interactions between the metal and the support[21]. Z. Yu et al. proposed a theoretical framework combining density functional theory calculations, aerodynamic modeling, Wulff-Kaichew constructions, and sintering kinetics simulations to elucidate the real-time reaction properties of loaded metal nanoparticles during sintering, addressing the decline in activity stemming from nanoparticle sintering [22]. Furthermore, J. Tian et al. identified that the deactivation of PtZn/γ-Al2O3 catalysts results from a reconstruction from PtZn IMA to Pt3Zn IMA [23]. This deactivation mechanism differs from conventional coke deposition and sintering, as it is driven primarily by metal-support interactions (MSI). To mitigate the loss of catalytic activity, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have garnered attention in ensuring catalyst stability [24]. MOFs serve as excellent templates for producing heterogeneous catalysts with superior catalytic activity. During thermal treatment in a controlled inert atmosphere, organic linkers decompose to yield highly porous carbon materials while atomically dispersed metal nodes become embedded within the carbon matrix. The morphology and properties of MOFs can be regulated by various factors, with solvent effects being particularly pronounced. These effects can influence nucleation rates, growth rates, crystal crystallinity, and overall morphology [25]. Different solvents, solvent mixtures, and varying ratios can yield diverse results. For instance, Moi et al. demonstrated that the dimensionality of the MOF could be controlled using binary solvent systems, the combination of both solvent types effectively modulated the dimensionality of the network[26]. Moreover, Ma et al. utilized the Kamlet-Taft parameter to effectively control the ratio of nucleation rate to growth rate of Mg-MOF-74, thereby regulating the crystal structure, morphology, and pore size of Mg-MOF-74, which in turn affected its CO2 adsorption performance [27]. However, employing MOFs as precursors can result in significant consumption of ligands derived from the petroleum industry, which poses environmental concerns. Renewable biomass feedstocks, such as FDCA, offer a sustainable alternative to fossil-based linkers in MOF synthesis. In recent years, while FDCA have been utilized in constructing metal organic frameworks (MOFs) [28–33], the solvent effects on Cu-MOF synthesis and their calcined catalysts for biomass conversion remain unexplored. To the best of our knowledge, systematic investigations into solvent effects via the Kamlet-Taft methodology particularly their relationship with the structural evolution of Cu-MOF and the catalytic behavior of their calcined derivatives have not yet been thoroughly explored. In this study, we synthesized a novel Cu-MOF by assembling Cu2 + ions with the biomass-derived ligand FDCA in various solvents under solvothermal conditions. This structural unit comprises two five-coordinate Cu2+ centers, connected in a bridging fashion via the FDCA ligand to the DMF [34]. Highly uniform carbon materials with allocated Cu nanoparticles (Cu/C-solvents) were prepared through direct pyrolysis at 500 °C in an inert atmosphere. We adjusted the Kamlet-Taft parameters by employing different solvents mixed with DMF, modifying both the structure of the Cu-MOF and the catalytic activity of the resultant calcined Cu/C catalyst. Notably, the catalysts obtained from DMF-MeOH mixed solvent exhibited excellent performance in the hydrogenation of LA to GVL. Furthermore, sequential reductions under H2 over five consecutive runs resulted in no significant loss of LA conversion. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO₃)₂·3H₂O, ≥ 99.5 %), anhydrous methanol (MeOH, ≥99.5 %), anhydrous ethanol (EtOH, ≥99.5 %), ethylene glycol (EG, ≥99.5 %), isopropanol (IPA, ≥99.5 %), n-hexane (≥99.5 %), and acetonitrile (≥99.5 %) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. 1-Octanol (98 %) was obtained from Sahn Chemical Technology Shanghai Co. N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.9 %), γ-valerolactone (GVL, 98 %), and levulinic acid (LA, 99 %) were sourced from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. Deionized water was prepared in the laboratory at Hefei University. 2,5-Furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA, 98 %) was purchased from Hefei Leaf Biotechnology Co. 4-nitroanisole (98 %) and 4-nitrophenol (99 %) were obtained from Adamas, and N, N-dimethylindoaniline (97 %) was purchased from Anergy Chemical Co. Terephthalic acid (PTA, 99 %) was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. 2.2 Synthesis of Cu-MOF precursor and Cu/C catalysts Cu-MOF was synthesized by solvothermal method. A typical preparation protocol was implemented as follows: initially, 1.208 g of Cu(NO₃)₂·3H₂O and 0.78 g of FDCA were dissolved in 80 mL of DMF in a flask placed in an oil bath at 150 °C with continuous stirring for 3 h. After cooling to room temperature, the mixture was filtered to obtain a blue solid, which was washed with 30 mL of DMF for 3 times. The washed solid was then dried under vacuum at 100 °C for 24 h to yield Cu-MOF precursor. For the convenience of future discussion, the resulting samples were named as Cu-MOF-D. For the synthesis of Cu-MOF with different solvents, 1.208 g of Cu(NO₃)₂·3H₂O and 0.78 g of FDCA were dissolved in a mixture of 40 mL DMF and 40 mL of a selected solvent (solvent=methanol, ethanol, ethylene glycol, isopropanol, octanol, water) in a flask in an oil bath at 150 °C with thorough stirring for 3 h. After cooling to room temperature, the mixture was filtered to obtain a solid. The photograph of the catalysts synthesized using different solvents was distinct as shown in Fig. S1. The solid was washed with 30 mL of the corresponding solvent for 3 times and dried under vacuum at 100 °C for 24 h. The resulting samples were labeled as Cu-MOF-DM, Cu-MOF-DE, Cu-MOF-DEG, Cu-MOF-DI, Cu-MOF-DO, and Cu-MOF-DH, respectively, according to the reaction solvents. The obtained Cu-MOF precursors were calcined in a tube furnace under a nitrogen flow (15 mL/min) at a heating rate of 5 °C/min to 500 °C and held for 2 h. The final catalysts were obtained and named as Cu/C-D, Cu/C-DM, Cu/C-DE, Cu/C-DEG, Cu/C-DI, Cu/C-DO, and Cu/C-DH, respectively. 2.3 Material characterization Cold field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed using a Hitachi SU8010. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out with a JEOL JEM-F200. X-ray diffractometry (XRD) was conducted using a Smart Lab SE equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed by means of a Thermo Fisher Scientific K-Alpha. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was carried out using a Shimazu IR Spirt-T. Gas chromatography (GC) was performed using a Hangzhou Jiedao GC-1690 model, with an Agilent Technologies column (30 m×0.25 mm×0.25 μm) and a temperature range of 40–260 °C. An ultraviolet-visible spectrophotometer (UV–vis) measurement was carried out using a Shimazu UV-2600. Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP) was performed using a Perkin Elmer Avio200. The specific surface and porosity analyzer (BET) used was the JW-BK 200. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was performed using a NETZSCH TG 209. The MS refinement of XRD is mainly based on the Rietveld method, which is implemented by Materials Studio (MS) software. Based on the known crystal structure, the initial structural model is inputted, and the Rietveld method is used to perform the least-squares fitting of the cell parameters and peak shape parameters, etc., to optimize the match between the model and the actual data, and the quality of the refinement is assessed by the goodness of the fit (e.g., the R-factor). The modified structural model and phase information were output. 2.4 Catalytic reactions The hydrogenation reaction of LA was carried out in a 25 mL autoclave, utilizing water as the solvent. Water, as an environmentally friendly and cos-effective solvent, aligns with the principles of green chemistry. Specifically, 25 mg of the Cu/C catalysts, 0.5 mmol of LA, and 8 mL of water were placed into the autoclave. Prior to the reaction, the autoclave was purged five times with hydrogen gas to eliminate the residual air. Subsequently, it was charged with hydrogen gas at a pressure of 3 MPa while stirring at a rate of 1000 rpm, after which the reaction mixture was heated to the designated reaction temperature. Upon completion of the reaction, the products were analyzed via gas chromatography (GC) equipped with a flame-ionization detector (model: Hangzhou Jiedao GC-1690, column: Agilent Technologies, with dimensions of 30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm and a temperature range of 40–260 °C). The liquid products, namely LA and GVL were quantified using the internal-standard method, with hexanol serving as the internal standard. The conversion of LA and the yield of GVL were calculated according to the following equations: (1) Conversion % = 1 − The molar amount of LA after the reaction Molar amount of LA before reaction × 100 % (2) Yield % = Molar amount of GVL Molar amount of LA before reaction × 100 % 2.5 Determination of solvent polarity parameters Kamlet-Taft parameters [35–38] serve as crucial indicators for characterizing the physicochemical properties of solvent molecules. In this study, these parameters are employed to gain insights into the chemical behavior of organic molecules within diverse solvents. The Kamlet-Taft parameters enable an in-depth assessment of the solvent's influence on aspects such as molecular solubility, reaction rate, and reaction mechanism. There are three key Kamlet-Taft parameters: α, β, and π*. The parameter α quantifies the hydrogen-bonding donating capacity (acidic nature), β represents the hydrogen-bonding accepting capacity (basicity), and π* reflects the polarity/polarizability, respectively [27,39]. These parameters are determined by exploiting the differences in the ground and excited-state dipole moments of dye molecules in solvents. As the solvent polarity varies, the position and intensity of the ultraviolet-visible (UV–vis) absorption spectrum exhibit significant changes. In this paper, three specific indicators are utilized to determine the Kamlet-Taft parameters. For the polarity parameter (π*), 4-nitroanisole is employed, as described by Eq. (3) [40–42]. The polarity (π*) values are normalized to zero with respect to cyclohexane. The indicator for the acidity parameter (α) in Eq. (4) is N,N- dimethylindoaniline [39]. For the basicity parameter (β), as presented in Eq. (5), 4-nitrophenol are used [40]. The distinct indicators are dissolved in various mixed solutions. Subsequently, the characteristic absorption peaks of the UV–vis absorption spectra in these solvent mixtures are measured, recorded, and organized. These data are then calculated using the equations corresponding to different polarity parameters [40–42,39,40]. (3) π* = 0.427 × (34.12- υmax） υ = 10000/λmax (4) α = （ XYZ − 53.389 + 3.367 π * ） - 5.607 XYZ = 28591/ υmax (5) β = 0.346 × (35.04 - υmax）- 0.57 × π* υ = 10000/λmax where λmax is the maximum absorption wavelength for the chromophore 4-nitroanisole in Eq. (3), the chromophore N,N-dimethylindoaniline in Eq. (4) and the chromophore 4-nitrophenol in Eq. (5). To standardize the parameters with the selected dye molecules, experimental data were calibrated using the Kamlet-Taft polarity parameters (α, β, and π*) for five different solvents (cyclohexane and ethanol, acetonitrile, isopropanol, and water) from the literature as shown in Table S1 and Fig. S2 in the supplementary material. It can be seen from Fig. S2 that the pure solvent value obtained after calibration is in good agreement with the reported value in the literature. 2.6 Theoretical calculations Molecular dynamics simulations and quantum chemistry calculations were performed using Materials Studio 2024 and Gaussian software, respectively. Intermolecular interactions were modeled using the COMPASS III force field during the simulation. To construct a structural model of the solution for the synthesis of Cu-MOF precursors, we followed the experimentally determined molar ratios. The solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DM precursors contains Methanol, DMF, FDCA and Cu²⁺. A solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DH precursors which contain H2O, DMF, FDCA, and Cu²⁺ was employed as a comparative system to elucidate interactions between solvent molecules and FDCA/Cu²⁺ species. Each simulation unit contains 3000–5000 atoms, ensuring the representativeness and complexity of the model. In the NPT ensemble (i.e. under fixed particle number, pressure and reaction temperature (423 K) conditions), we conducted long-term simulation operations to ensure that the system reached thermodynamic equilibrium. The function uses GGA-PBE, and the base set uses DND-4.4. After completing the molecular dynamics (MD) simulation, we utilized the analytical tools to calculate the Radial Distribution Function (RDF), Mean Square Displacement (MSD) for in-depth analysis of intermolecular interactions and structural properties. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of the catalyst In this study, the biomass-derived Cu/C catalysts were prepared by a solvent thermal method, the synthesis process and the structural evolution of the ultimate catalyst are summarized in Fig. 1. As an typical preparation process, the first step was to prepare Cu-MOF precursor, copper nitrate and FDCA were mixed in different solvents（methanol, ethanol, ethylene glycol, isopropanol, octanol, water）to self-assembly of various Cu-MOF under solvothermal conditions. The second step, the Cu/C catalysts were prepared by calcining the Cu-MOF precursor at 500 ℃ under nitrogen atmosphere to obtain a biomass-derived oxygen-rich carbon catalysts embedded with copper nanoparticles. To investigate the structure of the synthesized Cu-MOF precursors, a series of physicochemical characterizations were carried out on the catalysts synthesized in different solvents. Fig. 2a show the XRD pattern of the as-prepared Cu-MOF samples, the results show that the XRD pattern of the obtained materials were consistent with similar MOF structures reported in literature (CCDC: 2011138) [34], which confirming the successful construction of the biomass-derived Cu-MOF. In addition, as shown in the Fig. 2a, different solvents lead to minor variations, as the polarity of the solvent is crucial, and the mixtures with DMF have different polarities, resulting in structural changes in the Cu-MOF. Further refinement and characterization were required to confirm the exact structure of the synthesized MOF. In this study, Rietveld refinement of the X-ray diffraction (XRD) data was performed on the Cu-MOF-DM catalyst using the MS software package (Materials Studio) to elucidate its crystalline structure characteristics as shown in Fig. 2b. The initial model was based on a crystal structure similar to MOF (CCDC: 2011138), with a space group of P4/nmm and a unit cell parameter of a= 18.62 Å, b = 18.62 Å, c= 10.72 Å. During the refinement process, the unit cell parameters, atomic coordinates, and temperature factor were gradually adjusted, resulting in a decrease in Rwp from 17.2 % to 8.25 %, indicating a significant improvement in fitting quality. The experimental data (red circle) highly matches the calculated data (blue curve), and the positions and intensities of the main diffraction peaks (such as 2θ=9.52°,16.62°,19.06°) are consistent. The crystal structure diagram shows that the structural unit consists of two five-coordinated Cu²⁺ cations connected by the FDCA ligand in a bridging manner, weak stacking interactions bind the layers formed by the FDCA-linked units together, forming a three-dimensional pore structure. To further investigate the chemical structure of the as-synthesized Cu-MOF, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy characterization was performed on the synthesized materials. Fig. 2c displays the Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra of Cu-MOF-D, Cu-MOF-DM, Cu-MOF-DE, Cu-MOF-DEG, Cu-MOF-DI, Cu-MOF-DO, and Cu-MOF-DH. The peak at 3140 cm⁻¹ was attributable to the aromatic C-H stretching vibrations of the furan ring. The peak at 1364 cm⁻¹ was associated with the C-C stretching vibrations of the aromatic furan ring. The peaks at 1233 cm⁻¹ and 1098 cm⁻¹ correspond to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of C-O-C in the furan ring, respectively. The peak around 1014 cm⁻¹ corresponds to the bending vibrations of the furan ring, while the peaks at 976 cm⁻¹ , 818 cm⁻¹ , and 782 cm⁻¹ are attributed to the bending motions of 2,5-substituted furan. The presence of characteristic peaks in the furan ring indicates that the furan ring of FDCA was not destroyed during MOF synthesis, the FDCA, as a biomass-derived organic linker, has successfully coordinated with Cu metal nodes to form a stable Cu-MOFs framework. The signals at 2364 cm⁻¹ and 1630 cm⁻¹ are attributed to the -CH₃ vibrations and -CO vibrations of DMF, respectively. After deprotonation to -COO⁻ and coordination with Cu2+ ion, the carboxylic acid group (-COOH) of FDCA shifts its infrared peak from ∼1700 cm ⁻¹ (free -COOH) to low wave numbers of ∼1590–1405 cm⁻¹ (the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the COO⁻). The splitting between the two ν(COO) frequencies, Δ, is 185 cm⁻¹ , indicating successful deprotonation of the carboxylic acid group and coordination with the Cu2+ ion. Besides, a characteristic stretching vibration peak of C-O-Cu was observed at 1160 cm⁻¹ , further confirming the formation of metal ligand bond. The above results fully demonstrate the successful synthesis of the target MOF. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was further conduct to reveal the thermal stability and decomposition behavior of prepared catalysts as shown in Fig. 2d. The different TG curves represent the interactions between various solvent molecules and ligands. We measured the mass loss of Cu-MOF with different solvent under inert N₂ atmosphere. For the prepared seven Cu-MOF precursors, the mass loss can be roughly divided into the following three stages: the first stage occurs from 50 °C to about 240 °C, primarily associated with the evaporation of solvent molecules (DMF, methanol, ethanol, octanol, isopropanol, and water). The first stage for Cu-MOF-DEG observed at about 300 °C, likely due to the boiling point of EG being 197.3 °C, significantly higher than that of the other solvents. Moreover, the different solvents, when mixed with DMF, exhibit varying polarities and intermolecular interactions, potentially altering the thermal stability of the samples and thus influencing the TG curves. The second stage, occurring from 240 °C to about 325°C, is likely related to the release of ligand molecules and the decarboxylation of organic connecting groups. The third stage, observed after 400 °C, is characterized by the breaking of coordination bonds between the organic ligands and metal ion centers, leading to the collapse of the metal-organic framework, formation of porous biomass carbon materials. The pore structure of Cu-MOF was analyzed by nitrogen adsorption desorption isotherm. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm curves（Fig. S3 and Table S2）indicating that the synthesized Cu-MOF has a high specific surface area and good pore structure, which provides a foundation for its application in heterogeneous catalysis fields. The above characterization results indicate that the Cu-MOF precursors were successfully fabricated using FDCA, a biomass derivative, as a linker in different solvents through the solvothermal method. The morphology of the synthesized Cu-MOF precursors was analyzed by SEM ( Fig. 3), revealing a layered crystal structure characterized by stacked arrangements that form two-dimensional sheet-like architectures. Cu-MOF-D (Fig. 3a) synthesized in pure DMF exhibits lamellar structures, whereas the DMF/ethanol mixture (Cu-MOF-DE, Fig. 3c) yields thicker stacked layers. This aligns with ethanol’s higher polarity enhancing dipole-dipole interactions, thereby promoting layer stacking [40]. In contrast, solvents with reduced polarity (e.g., DMF/isopropanol and DMF/1-octanol) produce thinner and more fragmented flakes (Fig. 3e, f). When the polarity of the solution continues to increase, Fig. 3g shows the SEM image of the Cu-MOF precursor prepared in a mixture solvent of DMF and water, which results in a larger and denser stack of layers. Notably, methanol containing systems (Cu-MOF-DM, Fig. 3b, b1) form truncated octahedral structures due to methanol’s short carbon chain inducing hetero-crystalline phases, which are suppressed in longer-chain alcohols [41,42]. Ethylene glycol (Cu-MOF-EG, Fig. 3d), with dual hydroxyl groups, directs anisotropic growth into needle-like morphologies by selectively stabilizing specific crystal facets. These results demonstrate that solvent polarity and molecular structure (e.g., hydroxyl number, carbon chain length) critically govern Cu-MOF crystallization pathways and final architectures. The Cu-MOF precursors were subjected to calcination at 500 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere to obtain Cu/C catalysts. The crystalline structure of the synthesized catalysts was systematically investigated through X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. As illustrated in Fig. 4a, all Cu/C catalysts displayed similar XRD patterns with characteristic peaks corresponding to metallic copper (Cu) and cuprous oxide (Cu₂O), suggesting the coexistence of multiple copper species in the thermally treated samples. The primary diffraction peaks observed at 43.3°, 50.5°, and 74.2° were indexed to the (111), (200), and (220) crystallographic planes of face-centered cubic Cu (JCPDS 04–0836). Concurrently, distinct peaks at 37°, 42.6°, and 74.4° were assigned to the (111), (200), and (311) planes of cuprous oxide (JCPDS 34–1354). This multiphase composition was further confirmed by HRTEM analysis (Fig. 9c), which revealed the proximity of Cu⁰ nanoparticles to Cu₂O matrices in the Cu/C-DM catalyst. The synergistic interaction between metallic copper and cuprous oxide facilitates the formation of composite structures with optimized surface configurations that enhance catalytic activity. Although cuprous oxide was inherently unstable and prone to oxidation under ambient conditions, its stability during LA catalysis to produce GVL appears to be improved through copper interaction [43,44]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to analyze the surface chemical composition and electronic states of constituent elements, with the Cu/C-DM catalyst serving as a representative example. The XPS survey spectrum (Fig. 4b) confirmed the presence of Cu, C, and O elements on the catalyst surface, with binding energies referenced to the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. Deconvolution of the C 1 s spectrum (Fig. 4c) revealed three components at 284.8, 286.3, and 289.8 eV, corresponding to C-C bonds in aromatic networks, C-O bonds in hydroxyl groups, and CO moieties in carboxyl groups, respectively. The Cu 2p core-level spectrum (Fig. 4d) exhibited two characteristic peaks at 932.6 eV (Cu 2p₃/₂) and 952.5 eV (Cu 2p₁/₂), indicative of coexisting Cu⁰ and Cu⁺ species. In addition, the shake-up satellite peaks at about 940–947 eV and 959–966 eV further demonstrating the existence of Cu2+ species[45]. To resolve the overlapping binding energies of Cu⁰ and Cu⁺ in the Cu 2p region, Auger Cu LMM spectra were analyzed (Fig. 4e). Three distinct peaks at 916.27 eV, 917.1 eV, and 918.59 eV confirmed the coexistence of surface Cu⁺, Cu²⁺, and Cu⁰ species [46], respectively. The O 1 s spectrum (Fig. 4f) was resolved into three components at 530.8 eV (Cu-O bonds), 531.9 eV (C-O groups), and 533.9 eV (adsorbed oxygen species/CO groups) [47]. The XPS spectra of other Cu/C catalysts (Cu/C-D, Cu/C-DE, Cu/C-DEG, Cu/C-DI, Cu/C-DO, Cu/C-DH) synthesized in other solvents were shown in Fig. S4-S9, variations in solvent mixtures during synthesis led to significant differences in surface oxygen functionalities (C-O vs CO), as evidenced by comparative O 1 s spectra in Fig. S4-S9. These results collectively demonstrate that partially oxidized copper species are dispersed within oxygen-enriched carbon matrices containing both C-O and CO functional groups. 3.2 Catalytic performance of Cu/C catalysts in LA hydrogenation The hydrogenation of LA to GVL was systematically investigated using the Cu/C-DM catalyst under varying reaction conditions. As shown in Fig. 5a-c, the effects of reaction time, reaction temperature, and H₂ pressure on LA conversion and GVL yield were evaluated. The influence of reaction time on the hydrogenation of LA was investigated under fixed conditions (130 °C, 3 MPa H₂). As illustrated in Fig. 5a, the conversion of LA and the yield of GVL exhibited a strong dependence on reaction time. Both parameters increased progressively with prolonged duration, reaching optimal values at 6 h, complete substrate conversion (100 %) was achieved at this timepoint, accompanied by a near-quantitative product yield of 98.8 %. These findings highlight that 6 h represents the critical balance between maximizing reaction efficiency and ensuring selective product formation under the given catalytic system. Temperature dependence studies (Fig. 5b) revealed near-complete conversion (99.5 %) at 120 °C, while yield optimization required elevated temperatures, reaching 98.8 % and 99 % at 130 °C and 140 °C, respectively. Considering energy efficiency and environmental sustainability, 130 °C was selected as the optimal temperature. Similarly, H₂ pressure optimization (Fig. 5c) indicated that increasing pressure from 1 to 3 MPa dramatically improved conversion (from <5–100 %) and yield (from negligible to 98.8 %), confirming the critical role of sufficient hydrogen availability in driving the reaction. Additionally, we tested increased reaction pressure up to 3.5 MPa to further examine hydrogen pressure effects, the yield increased to 99.1 %. Given the marginal yield improvement at higher pressure, 3 MPa was selected as the reaction pressure considering economic and environmental factors. Based on the experimental results under the above conditions, optimal performance was achieved at 130 °C, 3 MPa H₂ pressure and 6 h, yielding complete LA conversion (100 %) with GVL yield of 98.8 %. Under these optimized conditions (130 °C, 3 MPa H₂, 6 h), the catalytic performance of the seven Cu/C catalysts synthesized in different solvents was compared as shown in Fig. 5d. Among them, the Cu/C-DM catalyst exhibited superior catalytic performance, achieving 100 % conversion and 98.8 % yield, significantly outperforming catalysts prepared in organic solvents such as ethylene glycol (71 % conversion, 51 % yield) or octanol (64.4 % conversion, 21.6 % yield). It is worth noting that we also prepared the catalyst (Cu/C-PTA) using the non-renewable ligand, terephthalic acid (PTA), in methanol and DMF under identical conditions and conducted control experiments. The results show that under otherwise identical conditions but changing only the ligand, the conversion of LA was only 48.7 %, and the yield of GVL was even lower at 23.3 %. This result further highlights the efficiency of the catalyst prepared using FDCA, a renewable biomass-derived ligand, as the linker in a suitable solvent. The catalytic performance of the Cu/C-DM catalyst was compared with some catalysts for LA hydrogenation reported in the literature, and the results were listed in Table S3. In the catalysts listed from entry 2–10, water was employed as the reaction solvent. However, typically require elevated temperatures (150–300 °C) and higher H₂ pressures (3–7 MPa) to achieve GVL yields of 72–100 %. In contrast, Cu/C-DM attains a superior yield of 98.8 % under significantly milder aqueous-phase conditions (130 °C, 3 MPa H₂, 6 h), demonstrating both energy efficiency and operational practicality. Notably, the catalyst in entry 6 and 7 contains precious metal Ag and Pt, which resulting in high catalyst costs. In the catalysts listed from entry 11–17, the solvents used were on organic solvents (e.g., methanol, 1,4-dioxane), which complicate product separation and raise environmental concerns. Additionally, the reaction temperatures exceeded 130 °C, and the yields were uniformly lower than 98.8 %. The catalysts listed as entry 18 and 19 are bimetallic catalysts. The solvents used were organic solvents, which deviates from the principles of green chemistry. In addition, the reaction temperatures were higher than 130 °C, and the H2 pressures were ≥ 3 MPa. In our study, the reaction pressure was maintained at 3, indicating relatively harsh reaction conditions. In the catalysts listed entry 20, the reaction temperature is high and the reaction time of 20 h is much longer than 6 h in our work. Stability is a very important performance for industrial catalysts, the recyclability of Cu/C-DM catalyst was evaluated over five consecutive reaction cycles under 130 °C for 6 h. Before each recycling experiment, the recovered Cu/C-DM was heated to 400 °C under H2 atmosphere for 3 h. As shown in Fig. S10, the catalyst retained 85.2 % of its conversion and the yield of GVL decreased marginally to 71.4 % after five cycles, demonstrating robust stability of Cu/C-DM catalyst. To further investigate whether the catalyst structure changes before and after the reaction, the recycled catalyst was compared with the fresh catalyst by XRD (shown in Fig. S11), and the comparison of the peak positions indicates no significant change in the crystal structure. Still, the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the recovered catalyst has decreased. By calculating the average size using the Scheller formula (as shown in Eqs S1), it was found that the average size of the metal particles in the catalyst increased by 1.82 nm after five cycles of recovery. The increase in the average size of metal particles also leads to a slight decrease in catalytic performance during the cycling process. In addition, the diffraction peaks of Cu2O almost disappeared after the cyclic reaction. This may be due to the fact that the catalyst is reduced under H2 atmosphere before each cycle, thus leading to the reduction of Cu2O to Cu, so the diffraction peaks almost disappeared. The exceptional combination of high activity, environmentally friendly reaction conditions, and recyclability positions Cu/C-DM as a promising catalyst for sustainable biomass conversion processes. 3.3 Influence mechanism 3.3.1 The influence of solvent effect determined by kamlet-taft method To elucidate the origin of the enhanced catalytic performance in Cu/C-DM catalyst, we prioritized investigating solvent effects during Cu-MOF precursor synthesis, given that the solvent constituted the sole variable across seven distinct catalyst preparation protocols. In the synthesis of MOFs, solvents affect the coordination equilibrium between the metal ion and the organic ligands through hydrogen bonding, regulating the nucleation, growth, and final pore structure of crystals [48–50]. Consequently, the Kamlet-Taft method was employed to obtain the reaction solvent's polarity parameters (α, β, π*), aiming to evaluate the hydrogen bonding formability of the solvents. In particular, α and β indicate the ability of the solvent to provide and accept hydrogen bonds, respectively [51,52] In this work, the polarity parameters of the seven solvents were measured through experimental methods. To ensure accuracy of the experiment, the parameters of Kamlet-Taft were tested for five standard solvents, the values of π*, α, and β in this study correspond well with that in literature as calibrated in Fig. S2 and Table S1. The growth of Cu-MOF depends on the deprotonation rate of organic ligand [53], as showed by α and β values. As summarized in Table 1, the polarity parameters (β/α value) of seven reaction solvents were determined by the Kamlet-Taft method [40,42,54] to provide a correlation between the β/α value and porous structure characteristics of Cu-MOF precursor. Since DMF has a considerable β value, the value of β/α is as high as 1.79, the solution has a strong ability to accept protons, which leads to excessive deprotonation of FDCA, resulting in a faster crystal nucleation rate than crystal growth rate, thus inhibiting crystal growth and cause the crystal aggregation. It can be seen that the Cu-MOF-D (Table 1 , Entry 1) has a smaller specific surface area (21.9 m2/g). When ethanol and ethylene glycol addition to DMF (Table 1 , Entry 3 and 4), β/α value showed a decreasing trend (1.34 and 1.14). This indicates that the solution has a strong ability to gives protons, which leads to a lower deprotonation of FDCA. This leads to overgrowth of crystals, which prolongs the nucleation process, resulting in a smaller specific surface area of the synthesized Cu-MOF-DE (16.4 m2/g) and Cu-MOF-DEG (12.6 m2/g) precursor. In contrast, with the adding of isopropanol and 1-octanol to DMF (Table 1 , Entry 5 and 6), the β/α value slightly decreased relative to pure DMF, but still high (1.59 and 1.74). The FDCA undergoes excessive deprotonation, inhibiting crystal growth, resulting in a smaller specific surface area of the synthesized Cu-MOF-DI (5.5 m2/g) and Cu-MOF-DO (7.1 m2/g) precursor. The higher α value of H2O (solely a hydrogen bond donor) reduced the β/α ratio of DMF/H2O to 0.72 (Table 1 , Entry 7), lowering the solvent's proton-accepting ability. This suppressed FDCA deprotonation, leading to Cu-MOF-DH with a reduced surface area (7.2 m²/g). When methanol was added to DMF (Table 1 , Entry 2), the β/α value was at a moderate level around 1.45 and organic ligands reach a coordination equilibrium. It induced a balance between the nucleation and growth rates of the crystals so that the Cu-MOF-DM achieve synergistic optimization of high surface area (59.1 m2/g). At the same time, the pore volume of the Cu-MOF can be controlled by adjusting β/α value of the solvent. From Table 1, it can be clearly found that the Cu-MOF-DM possess the maximum pore volume (0.121 cm3/g). The specific surface area of the Cu-MOF precursors follows a volcano-type trend with the β/α value of reaction solvents (DMF + solvent: methanol, ethanol, ethylene glycol, isopropanol, octanol, water) ( Fig. 6a). The solution (DMF + methanol) has a moderate value that can facilitated the growth of Cu-MOF-DM, which resulted in a large surface area. With increasing β/α value, the specific surface area of Cu-MOF precursors increased first and then decreased. This highlights the critical role of optimizing β/α value for maximizing pore structure of Cu-MOF porosity and thereby changing hydrogenation performance of calcined Cu/C catalyst. As shown in Fig. 6b and Table S4, the β/α value observably affected the hydrogenation properties of Cu/C catalyst. The yield of GVL reached 98.8 % at the optimal β/α value (β/α = 1.45), which was much higher than that of other β/α value. Overall, the β/α value controls the deprotonation function of FDCA, thus affecting the coordination balance between Cu2+ and organic ligands. The pore structure of Cu-MOF relied on the β/α value, which could further affect the hydrogenation performance of calcined Cu/C catalysts. The origin of enhanced activity will be thoroughly discussed in the following chapters. While the Cu-MOF-DM prepared in MeOH/DMF precursors (β/α = 1.45) demonstrated superior copper dispersion and porosity, the origin of this enhancement was unresolved. By employing molecular dynamics simulations, we have been able to further elucidate the solvation structure of Cu2+ ions in synthetic solution to probe solvent-FDCA/Cu²⁺ interactions. The structural configurations obtained from MD simulations of the solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DM precursors and the solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DH precursors were presented in Fig. 7a and b, respectively. The radial distribution functions of Cu2+ ions, illustrated in Fig. 7c and d, offer a comprehensive depiction of their solvation shells. The solvation structure of Cu2+ in synthetic solution is significantly influenced by the types of synthetic solution. As shown in Fig. 7c, in the precursor solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DM, the Cu²⁺ ions are primarily solvated by methanol molecules, forming two distinct Cu-O(MeOH) peaks. In contrast, in the precursor solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DH (Fig. 7d), the Cu²⁺ ions are mainly solvated by H2O molecules, forming two distinct Cu-O(H₂O) peaks. Notably, the prominent peak for the Cu-O(MeOH) pair in the Cu-MOF-DM precursor solution reveals a stronger interaction between Cu²⁺ and MeOH. Furthermore, the RDF profiles for Cu-N(DMF) and Cu-O(FDCA) pairs are similar in both solutions, exhibiting weak peaks with the first peak position above 4 Å. This indicates that Cu²⁺ is primarily solvated by methanol and water in their respective precursor solutions, with a stronger interaction between Cu²⁺ and methanol. By performing dynamic simulations of both the solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DM precursors and for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DH precursors, we obtained the Mean Square Displacement curves of Cu2+. Based on kinetic theory, when the MSD curve displays a linear correlation, the self-diffusion coefficient (D) can be directly determined from the linear relationship between MSD and time. The analysis results show that the slope of the MSD curve for Cu2+ in the solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DM is significantly lower than that in the solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DH, corresponding to diffusion coefficients of 2.42 × 10− 5 cm2 /s and 2.78 × 10− 4 cm2 /s, respectively. These results suggest that Cu2+ ions exhibit a higher diffusion rate in the solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DH. The enhanced diffusion kinetics in the solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DH may promote rapid nucleation for Cu-MOF and subsequent diffusion of Cu2+ ions, which are crucial for dictates framework assembly. In the solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DM precursors (e.g., MSD = 2.42 × 10− 5 cm2 /s), restricted diffusion imposes diffusion-limited growth, slowing nucleation and enabling thermodynamically controlled assembly. This yields highly crystalline frameworks with optimal porosity and minimal defects. Conversely, the solution for synthesizing Cu-MOF-DH precursors (e.g., MSD = 2.78 × 10− 4 cm2 /s) promote rapid, reaction-limited kinetics. Accelerated ion mobility induces fast nucleation and disordered aggregation, resulting in defective frameworks with collapsed porosity and reduced surface area. The MSD differential as a key design parameter for achieving structurally ordered MOF catalysts via diffusion-controlled crystallization. 3.3.2 Effects of porosity and morphology of the Cu/C catalysts In hydrogenation reactions, catalyst performance is governed by multiple factors, with pore architecture and metal loading emerging as critical determinants of mass transport efficiency and active site accessibility. As summarized in Table 2, control experiments with the blank catalyst (Table 2 , Entry 1) confirmed no detectable product formation. Among the seven catalysts evaluated, Cu/C-DM (Table 2, Entry 3) demonstrated exceptional performance. Notably, Cu/C-DE (Table 2, Entry 4), despite possessing the highest specific surface area (317.9 m²/g) and elevated copper loading (71.6 wt%) as determined by ICP-OES analysis, catalytic activity was not as good as that of Cu/C-DM. Cu/C-DM exhibited the lowest copper content (42.54 wt%) within the catalyst series. We attribute this phenomenon to the synergistic interaction between DMF and methanol during synthesis, which not only induced a unique hierarchical morphology but also generated optimally sized mesopores (5.7 nm). These structural features facilitated rapid diffusion of LA molecules while enabling uniform dispersion of copper active sites, thereby maximizing their accessibility. In contrast, Cu/C-D (Table 2, Entry 2); Cu/C-DGE (Table 2 , Entry 5); Cu/C-DI (Table 2 , Entry 6); Cu/C-DO (Table 2 , Entry 7) and Cu/C-DH (Table 2 , Entry 8) possessing similar specific surface area and Cu loading but exhibited lower yield rate, which suggests that the differences in catalytic performance may not be attributed to surface area alone. Therefore, we further investigated the morphology of the seven Cu/C catalysts using HRTEM to examine the Cu nanoparticle dispersion on the catalyst surface. The Cu/C-DM catalyst exhibits uniformly dispersed Cu nanoparticles with minimal aggregation, as evidenced by TEM analysis (Fig. S12). In contrast, catalysts synthesized in other solvents display severe Cu sintering and particle agglomeration. This structural degradation correlates with significantly reduced catalytic activity, emphasizing the critical role of solvent-mediated dispersion in preserving accessible active sites. The N₂ physisorption isotherms (Fig. S13) of the seven catalysts indicating that the catalyst has a mesoporous structure, with pore sizes mainly below 10 nanometers. Based on the characterization results of the pore structure (Table 2 and Fig. S14) and morphology (Fig. S12) of the seven Cu/C catalysts mentioned above, it was shown that the Cu/C catalysts synthesized under different solvents have similar specific surface areas but different distribution of Cu nanoparticles. This finding highlight that the surface properties of Cu nanoparticles such as electronic interactions or geometric interaction may play more critical roles in determining catalytic activity and this prompts us to continue our research in-depth. 3.3.3 The role of Cu electronic and geometric properties on the LA hydrogenation To obtain further insight into the relationship between the electronic properties of Cu and catalytic performance of the Cu/C samples, we analyze the chemical states of Cu on the catalysts surface by X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) and the Cu LMM Auger spectra. The previous XPS results (Fig. 4d and Fig. S4-S9) represent the coexistence of the Cu2+ and Cu+/0 state on Cu/C samples. Detailed valence states of Cu were then analyzed by using the Cu LMM Auger spectra. As presented in Fig. 8a-g, all samples displayed similar Cu LMM Auger spectra, where the kinetic energy of the Auger electron transitions of the seven Cu/C catalysts corresponding to Cu2+, Cu+ and Cu0 are measured at 917.1, 916.2 and 918.4 eV, respectively, indicating the partially oxidized Cu species on the Cu/C catalysts [55,56]. The quantitative amounts of Cu2+, Cu+ and Cu0 in the seven Cu/C catalysts synthesized in different solvents were calculated by the XPS fitting results of Cu LMM spectra, which are summarized in Fig. 8h. For the Cu/C-DM catalyst (Fig. 8h, Entry 2), the contents of Cu0 species were 49 % which is the highest among all catalysts. The elevated content of Cu0 species in the Cu/C-DM catalyst might be derive from the distinctive architecture and surface topography of the Cu-MOF-DM precursor, particularly considering that solvent is the only variable in the seven catalysts. As reported, Cu nanoparticles, regarded as active sites for H2 activation, can dissociate adsorbed H2 to form highly active and mobile H atoms, which easily react with the neighboring activated -CO groups to produce GVL [57,58]. Therefore, the higher content of Cu0 species in the Cu/C-DM catalyst could be responsible for the high conversion rate observed in LA hydrogenation. Other catalysts (e.g., Cu/C-DI (Fig. 8h, Entry 5), Cu/C-DO (Fig. 8h, Entry 6), Cu/C-DH (Fig. 8h, Entry 7)) have comparatively high Cu0 content but lower conversion rates due to Cu nanoparticle aggregation, as shown in the TEM image (Fig. S12). Thus, correlating the content of Cu0 with LA conversion is capable of revealing its key role in the hydrogenation process as shown in Fig. S14. While LA conversion generally correlates with surface Cu⁰ content, the Cu/C-DE catalyst deviates from this trend (Fig. 8h, Entry 6), achieving high activity despite low Cu⁰ exposure. This shows that other factors, such as Cu dispersion and the effects of Cu+ and Cu2+ copper species, can also affect the hydrogen performance. It has been demonstrated a synergistic effect between Cu0 and Cu+, with Cu0 facilitating H2 dissociation and Cu+ perform as the Lewis acid sites to activate the carbonyl moieties by side-bond interaction [59,60]. Combined with the Cu LMM Auger spectra data, we calculated the (Cu0 + Cu+)/Cu2+ atomic ratios for all samples (Fig. 8h). The yield of GVL exhibited a positive correlation with the (Cu⁰ + Cu⁺)/Cu²⁺ ratio. At lower ratios of 2.03 (Cu/C-DEG, Entry 4) and 2.45 (Cu/C-DO, Entry 6), the yield was significantly reduced to 51 % and 21.6 %, respectively. As the ratio (Cu⁰ + Cu⁺)/Cu²⁺ increased, the yield progressively improved, reaching 70.45 % at 2.7 (Cu/C-D, Entry 1), 78 % at 3.17 (Cu/C-DE, Entry 3). The Cu/C-DM catalyst (Entry 2) achieved the highest (Cu⁰ + Cu⁺)/Cu²⁺ atomic ratio of 4.56 among all catalysts, which corresponded to the maximum GVL yield of 98.8 %. Notably, two additional catalysts with comparable ratios 3.54 (Cu/C-DI, Entry 5) and 4.26 (Cu/C-DH, Entry 7) demonstrated substantially lower yields of 43 % and 29 %, respectively. HRTEM analysis (Fig. S12) and particle size distribution histograms of Cu nanoparticles supported on Cu/C-DM and Cu/C-DH (Fig. S15) revealed pronounced Cu aggregation in these underperforming catalysts, which likely contributed to their diminished catalytic efficiency through reduced active surface area or altered electronic properties. In a word, during hydrogenolysis of LA, Cu0 activates H2, while Cu+ adsorbs the carbonyl groups of LA, the superior performance of the Cu/C-DM catalyst partially originates from the synergistic interaction between metallic Cu⁰ and Cu⁺ species. While the electronic effects of Cu in Cu/C-DM catalysts play a key role in determining catalytic activity, the geometric effects, such as the arrangement and exposure of Cu species (Fig. S14), also influence the overall catalytic performance. In this study, we selected the highest performing Cu/C-DM catalyst to examine the dispersion of Cu species on its surface, aiming to delve into the connection between Cu geometric effect and catalytic performance. As can be seen in the TEM image and corresponding EDS mapping ( Fig. 9 a-b), elemental mapping confirms homogeneous spatial distribution of Cu, C, and O species throughout the catalyst matrix, which indicated that the Cu nanoparticles are highly dispersed on the support without obvious aggregation for the Cu/C-DM catalyst. High resolution TEM (HRTEM) images show that there are two kinds of lattice fringes with inter-planar spacing of 0.2060 nm assigned to (111) of the Cu₂O, where the (111) fringes of Cu (d=0.2395 nm) are located at the external surfaces of Cu in Cu/C-DM catalyst (Fig. 9c). This result indicating the generate of Cu/Cu2O nanojunctions on the catalyst surface, the unique electric field at the Cu/Cu2O interface creates special electronic properties, as proven by Cu LMM Auger spectra (Fig. 8). 4 Conclusion FDCA, derived from abundant and low-cost biomass, features a low-carbon footprint, environmentally friendly production process, the technological advances in production are driving capacity expansion and market expansion. In contrast, petroleum-based ligands face limited feedstocks and significant environmental burdens. Using FDCA as the ligand, we successfully controlled the textural properties of biomass-derived Cu-MOF by tuning the solvent type. The β/α value at a moderate level induced a balance between the nucleation and growth rates of the crystals so that the Cu-MOF-DM precursor achieves synergistic optimization of high specific surface area and well-defined morphology. After calcination, the Cu/C-DM catalyst exhibits superior catalytic activity, selectivity and stability in hydrogenation of LA into GVL. The superior performance of the Cu/C-DM catalyst stems from the synergistic interaction between Cu⁰ and Cu⁺ species. HRTEM and EDS analyses confirm the geometric effects of highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles without aggregation. Meanwhile, Cu Auger spectra reveal electronic effects through Cu⁰/Cu⁺ coexistence. This dual synergy of geometric dispersion and electronic structure contributes to the catalyst's enhanced catalytic activity. This work provides a unique perspective for the regulation of the biomass-based Cu-MOFs structure by solvent polarity modulation based on the Kamlet-Taft method and clarified how various Cu species synergistically catalyze hydrogenation reactions eﬃciently. Catal. 380 (2019) 289-296. Weimeng Cai is an Associate Professor at the School of Energy Materials & Chemical Engineering, Hefei University. She received her Ph.D. in Chemistry from Nanjing University. Her research interests center on heterogeneous catalysis and biomass catalytic conversion, with a specific focus on designing advanced catalytic systems for hydrogenation reactions. Dr. Cai has published over 10 peer-reviewed papers in prestigious journals such as ACS Catalysis and Chinese Journal of Catalysis. Currently, her work aims to develop efficient catalysts for sustainable biomass valorization, addressing challenges in renewable energy and green chemistry. (Email: caiwm@hfuu.edu.cn)

coredata.dc:description: The synthesis of value-added chemicals from renewable biomass is becoming increasingly important in the transition to a sustainable and low-carbon energy system. Herein, we demonstrate a solvent-polarity modulation strategy to engineer biomass-derived Cu-MOF using 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) as a renewable ligand, where tailored β/α ratios via Kamlet-Taft parameters balance nucleation-growth kinetics to optimize textural properties. Pyrolyzed Cu-MOF at 500 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere yield the Cu/C catalysts, which were subsequently employed in the selective hydrogenation of levulinic acid (LA) to γ-valerolactone (GVL). Among the various solvents used, the Cu-MOF precursor synthesized in a mixed solvent of methanol and N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) demonstrated the highest catalytic performance, outperforming those synthesized in other solvents. This highlights the significant impact of solvent selection on the structure of Cu-MOF, which in turn affects their hydrogenation activity. Advanced characterization confirming that the uniform Cu dispersion (confirmed by HRTEM mapping) and Cu⁰/Cu⁺ electronic synergy (via Cu Auger analysis) enhanced hydrogenation performance. Additionally, the biomass-derived catalysts exhibited excellent durability. Overall, this research provides a promising approach to develop highly efficient catalysts using renewable ligands and demonstrates the potential of regulating catalyst properties through the strategic selection of solvents, as informed by Kamlet-Taft parameters.
